newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST - Australian General News - Sept 26.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST - Australian General News - Sept 26.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

In contrast to statements by Prime Minister Howard and other senior ministers, new Reserve Bank governor Ian Macfarlane said yesterday the government's proposed industrial relations reforms would have very little effect on employment and joblessnss in the short term. Macfarlane's comments followed criticism of the government's description of the fiscal position as a "black hole" by former Reserve Bank governor Bernie Fraser. Page 1.

The Law Institute yesterday gave overwhelming support to a proposal by Chief Justice of Australia, Gerard Brennan, which calls for greater use of cheaper and quicker methods of dispute resolution, such as mediation and arbitration, to clear the logjam of complex and lengthy trials in the courts. Page 2.

Federal Treasurer Peter Costello and New Zealand Finance Minister Bill Birch last week agreed to a six-month work programme to examine ways of overcoming double taxation on dividend income, in a motion that removes one of the last outstanding tax and investent issues of the Closer Economic Relations (CER) agreement between the two countries. Page 3.

Launching a land access summary by the Bureau of Resource Sciences yesterday, Resources Minister Warwick Parer said the government was likely to allow mining and exploration in areas classified by the Australian Heritage Commission as having "high wildernss value". Parer said the Coalition would improve the operation of the Native Title Act and environmental impact assessments and favour multiple land use. Page 3.
THE AUSTRALIAN

A week after taking up the position of Reserve Bank governor, Ian McFarlane told the annual Conference of Economists in Canberra yesterday that the Government's industrial relations reforms would have little effect on employment in the short-term, with most of the effect being on productivity and long-run growth. Page 1.

Although Prime Minister John Howard last night defended the right of Independent MP Pauline Hanson to speak out on controversial issues, he rejected her views on Asian immigration, stating Australia has a non-discriminatory immigration policy. Howard also dismissed a challenge from right-wing British historian David Irving to overturn a ban by the former Labor Government on his entry to Australia, calling him a "crackpot" and an opportunist. Page 1.

Continuing a war of words with university vice-chancellors, Education Minister Amanda Vanstone yesterday ridiculed them for their fierce reaction to her comments which played down the impact of budget cuts on universities. Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee president Fay Gales said yesterday the minister had been "completely wrong" to suggest universities were afraid of change when all the evidence suggests the contrary. Page 1.

Following France's signing of a global nuclear test ban treaty yesterday, the federal government will consider lifting the eight-year-old ban on new uranium contracts with the nation, making way for a three to four-fold increase in Australian exports to France and an improvement in the battered relationship between the two countries. Page 1.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

In his first public appearance as Reserve Bank governor, Ian Macfarlane yesterday embarrassed the government by rejecting the key selling point of its industrial relations reforms, saying it was possible the reforms would have very little effect on employmnt and would serve only to boost productivity and long-term economic growth. Page 1.

A Darwin man suffering from prostrate cancer has become the first person in the world to die using euthanasia legislation. With his wife and doctor beside him, Dr Philip Nitschke, the man died on the weekend after pressing the required buttons on a compuer-operated driver which administered the lethal drugs. Page 1.

Following comments by International Olympic Committee official Dr Jacques Rogge about a potential problem with Aborigines and ethnic groups taking the Sydney Games as a "hostage", Aboriginal leader Charles Perkins last night accused the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games of arranging the remarks to threaten Aboriginal people. Page 1.

In China's People's Daily newspaper, Australia was today accused of being "in league with the devil" by agreeing to meet with the Dalai Lama. The article said Prime Minister John Howard's assertions that the Tibetan leader is being recognised only as a rligious figure are "absurd". Page 1.
THE AGE

Victorians were shaken yesterday by the biggest earthquake to rock the state in nearly 14 years. The earthquake measured five on the Richter scale and the epicentre was a few kilometres south-east of Mount Baw Baw. Its impact was felt up to 135 km away, including areas of metropolitan Melbourne. Page A1.

The fairy-tale rise to stardom for the Sydney Swans which will climax in the AFL grand final this weekend, apparently is still in financial trouble according to confidential documents obtained by The Age, revealing debts of A$2.5 million. Page A1.

Federal Finance Minister John Fahey has fuelled Australia's airport privatisation debate by attacking politicians who want their airports locally owned. In remarks directed towards Victorian Premier Jeff Kennett, Fahey said the federal government would no be browbeaten by politicians seeking some electoral advantage. Page A3.

Victoria's gambling boom may not be good news for some but it is a bonanza for senior executives at Crown Casino and Tabcorp, who have been paid out as much as A$1.6 million and A$1.3 million respectively, according to audit figures. Page A3.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 373-1800
